page.title: 16Crofting at Unapool
page.content: One of the crofters at Unapool has been crofting for over sixty years. He remembers as a boy helping his parents look after their one cow _ a necessity for fresh milk in those days _ and eight sheep-the most the local farmer would let them keep. Now he has a flock of 150 sheep, all Cheviots, a breed introduced from the Borders at the time of the Clearances. His lambing takes place in April and he hopes for about 90 lambs, depending on the weather conditions. The females he keeps,the males and old ewes he sells at the Dingwall sales in September. His busiest time is from July to October when he is either gathering, clipping, dipping or marking. Our crofter likes the hill work best_ when he is out all day with only his dogs for company.
